body:
>> One slight concern is that i'm not sure if the contents (i.e. used keys) of this histogram will be discoverable.

> Could you please elaborate on that, please? I can see that the different keys of remote settings were discovered properly on the telemetry measurement dashboard :)

Sure!
They will show up in dashboards, but i can't get a single list of all the values that we can expect:

- As a data steward, i can't see all the reported values in one place.
- As a data engineer, i can't tell easily which values are valid/expected and which not.
- As an implementing engineer or analyst, i can't easily tell which values are missing.

>> Another is that all the recipes will be mixed in with all other uptake users; having this in a separate probe would be cleaner and less fragile for processing.

> That was part of our initial goal: have a central location where we can get every kind of uptake at a glance.

Which is great. I think this works well where you want to measure uptake of single, not strongly related items.
For cases where multiple items of the same type are being reported, you have to use work-arounds though to e.g. get totals (string prefix parsing etc.).
This works, but is fragile (relies on conventions, not enforced semantics).
Having those kinds of values in separate histograms would be more clean.

But... maybe we should take this conversation out of this issue :)
I was mainly trying to summarize the offline conversation about options here.

One slight concern is that i'm not sure if the contents (i.e. used keys) of this histogram will be discoverable.

Could you please elaborate on that, please? I can see that the different keys of remote settings were discovered properly on the telemetry measurement dashboard :)

Sure!
They will show up in dashboards, but i can't get a single list of all the values that we can expect:

  • As a data steward, i can't see all the reported values in one place.
  • As a data engineer, i can't tell easily which values are valid/expected and which not.
  • As an implementing engineer or analyst, i can't easily tell which values are missing.

Another is that all the recipes will be mixed in with all other uptake users; having this in a separate probe would be cleaner and less fragile for processing.

That was part of our initial goal: have a central location where we can get every kind of uptake at a glance.

Which is great. I think this works well where you want to measure uptake of single, not strongly related items.
For cases where multiple items of the same type are being reported, you have to use work-arounds though to e.g. get totals (string prefix parsing etc.).
This works, but is fragile (relies on conventions, not enforced semantics).
Having those kinds of values in separate histograms would be more clean.

But... maybe we should take this conversation out of this issue :)
I was mainly trying to summarize the offline conversation about options here.
